description: Introduced by Coleridge, based on German Clerisei (modern Klerisei), from Late Latin clÄ“ricus.

entries.meaning: An elite group of intellectuals; learned people, the literati.
The clergy, or their opinions, as opposed to the laity.
examples: Few men have ever had a stronger conviction of their clerisy, of their belonging to the clerkly caste of the responsibles.
